title: 110_hr6102
content: The Act titled "Health Care Paperwork Reduction and Fraud Prevention Act of 2008" includes the establishment of a National Bipartisan Commission on Billing Codes and Forms Simplification. The Commission on Billing Codes and Forms Simplification is established to recommend standardized and simplified forms, reduce billing codes, and reform regulatory processes in healthcare claims. The Commission on Billing Codes and Forms Simplification provides guidance to healthcare providers for submitting claims under Medicare and aims to prevent targeting inadvertent billing errors. It consists of 17 members appointed by the President, Senate majority leader, and Speaker of the House. The Commission also focuses on simplifying and updating electronic forms for Medicare and Medicaid services. The Commission on Billing Codes and Forms Simplification consists of 17 members appointed by various officials. Members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Provisions from the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 apply to the Commission. The Commission on Billing Codes and Forms Simplification, consisting of 17 members appointed by various officials, must adhere to provisions from the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. The Commission is required to submit a report to the President and Congress by December 31, 2008, containing only recommendations, findings, and conclusions approved by at least 11 members. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. SEC. 3. EDUCATION OF PHYSICIANS AND PROVIDERS ON MEDICARE PAYMENTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a process for physicians to request assistance with Medicare billing codes. The carrier must respond within 30 days with the correct information. Requests can be used as proof in audits, except for cases of fraudulent billing. The Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will restore a toll-free hotline for physicians to inquire about the Medicare program. Definitions for "physician" and "carrier" are provided in this section. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. SEC. 4. Policy development for E&M guidelines under Medicare program. The Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services must follow specific steps before implementing new evaluation and management guidelines (E&M guidelines) under the Medicare program, including physician assessment, goal establishment, pilot projects in different regions, and ensuring objectives are met. Each pilot project under this subsection must be of sufficient length for preparatory education, analysis, and assessment of potential E&M guidelines. Projects must also be conducted in consultation with national and State medical societies. Additionally, at least one pilot project will focus on peer review by physicians evaluating medical record information for statistical outlier services relative to CPT book guidelines. The pilot projects will examine the impact of E&M guidelines on different physician practices and costs of compliance. A report on meeting objectives must be submitted to relevant committees within 6 months after the conclusion of the projects. The pilot projects will assess the impact of E&M guidelines on physician practices and compliance costs. A report on meeting objectives must be submitted to relevant committees within 6 months after the projects end. The objectives include enhancing documentation accuracy, reducing administrative burdens, decreasing non-clinical documentation, improving reviewer accuracy, and educating physicians and reviewers. The pilot projects will evaluate the effects of E&M guidelines on physician practices and compliance costs. Key aspects include education of physicians and reviewers, appropriate use of E&M codes, adherence to CPT coding rules, and simplifying electronic billing. Definitions for terms like physician, carrier, and Secretary are also provided. The term "Medicare program" refers to the program under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. SEC. 5. OVERPAYMENTS UNDER THE MEDICARE PROGRAM. Individualized Notice: Carriers must inform physicians of billing issues within 3 months of a post-payment audit, offering suggestions for resolution. Repayment of Overpayments: Physicians can repay Medicare overpayments within 3 months without penalty or interest, and without denial of other claims. If physicians identify overpayments before being notified by carriers, they can reimburse without penalty, and the Secretary cannot audit or target them. If a physician makes a first-time Medicare billing error and has not been audited before, the carrier cannot fine them through extrapolation unless a fraudulent claim is submitted. Carriers must notify physicians of potential claim issues within one year before using extrapolation for reimbursement or penalties. Physicians can dispute carrier charges by submitting additional information and documentation. Following a post-payment audit, a carrier conducting a pre-payment screen on a physician service under Medicare cannot delay reimbursements for more than one month. Once the physician submits a corrected claim, the carrier must remove the pre-payment screen.
